intro: Quercus macroloba, commonly known as the large-leaf oak, is a deciduous tree native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is characterized by its broad, elliptical leaves that are typically 8–15 cm in length. The tree produces small, urn-shaped acorns that are often covered in a dense layer of fuzzy hairs. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Quercus macroloba plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
